feed.title: Combined summary - Adding New BIP Editors

entry.title: Combined summary - Adding New BIP Editors
entry.summary:
The discussions within the Bitcoin Development Mailing List highlight several points concerning the Bitcoin Improvement Proposals (BIP) process. A significant issue raised involves the need to streamline the BIP editing and reviewing process. It's suggested that rather than having editors check for technical soundness, their role should focus on ensuring each proposal is relevant to the Bitcoin ecosystem and adheres to minimal formal criteria. This approach would not only alleviate the workload on editors but also shift the responsibility of evaluating technical soundness to the BIP audience.
There's a consensus on the necessity of enhancing the BIP process by adding more editors to address backlogs in number assignment and approved changes to existing BIPs. The idea of involving non-developer triaging for simple issues and modifications to BIPs has been introduced, emphasizing that anyone with a good understanding of the process could contribute without needing special permissions. This would expedite addressing straightforward concerns in newly proposed BIPs.
Several individuals have been proposed as potential candidates for new BIP editors, reflecting a desire to include those with a history of involvement and objective evaluation in Bitcoin development. The importance of selecting editors capable of managing and merging BIPs effectively is underscored, with specific names mentioned as suitable choices. However, there are differing opinions on whether the BIP repository should remain centralized or if multiple repositories for BIPs would be preferable.
Furthermore, the discussion touches on the logistical aspects of assigning BIP numbers and the challenges involved in assessing new proposals' criteria. There's an acknowledgment of the immediate need to appoint more editors to manage the increasing volume of proposals and updates efficiently.
Overall, the correspondence among members of the Bitcoin Development Mailing List reflects a collective effort to refine the BIP process. The emphasis is on making the procedure more inclusive and efficient by potentially broadening the pool of contributors and simplifying the editorial responsibilities to focus on adherence to formal criteria and relevance to the Bitcoin ecosystem.
